title: Lancashire father chases 'terrified' puppy with wood
title_page: Lancashire father chases 'terrified' puppy with wood | Daily Mail Online
text:
This is the sickening moment a father chased a 'terrified' puppy with a plank of wood around his garden in a video filmed by a horrified neighbour.
Christopher Dennett, of Buckshaw Village, Lancashire, was seen swinging the block wildly as his dog Narla barked and ran away.
But the 30-year-old lorry driver claimed was trying to train the Dogue de Bordeaux puppy by emulating an exercise he had seen on YouTube.
Shocking video: Christopher Dennett, of Buckshaw Village, Lancashire, was seen swinging the plank of wood wildly as his dog Narla barked and ran away
The 30-year-old lorry driver (left) claimed was trying to train his Dogue de Bordeaux puppy Narla (right) by emulating an exercise he had seen on YouTube
Now, he has admitted causing unnecessary suffering towards the dog by using threatening or abusive behaviour, and been banned from keeping animals for a year.
The defendant handed over the animal to the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which said it was 'emotionally not in a good way'.
RSPCA Inspector Helen Smith said: 'As you can see from the video, Narla is terrifed, and has been caused unnecessary suffering, fear and distress.
'She is now terrified of men and although we could find no significant physical harm, emotionally she is not in a good way.'
Dennett has admitted causing unnecessary suffering towards the dog by using threatening or abusive behaviour, and been banned from keeping animals for a year
The defendant handed over the animal to the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which said it was 'emotionally not in a good way'
The court was shown the sickening 47-second video in which the frightened dog is heard barking and seen running away as he swings at her with the wood.
A horrified neighbour had captured the back garden attack and rang police who then sent the footage to the RSPCA.
But Dennett laughed off the investigation, telling RSPCA workers he was trying to train the dog for close quarters protection for his girlfriend.
However, Dennett – who has no previous convictions - was disqualified from keeping dogs for 12 months and was ordered to pay a £660 fine along with a £66 surcharge.
